title: Book of the Dead
summary: The Book of the Dead (Egyptian: ğ“‚‹ğ“¤ğ“ˆ’ ğ“Œğ“¤ ğ“‰ğ“‚‹ ğ“ğ“‚» ğ“…“ ğ“‰”ğ“‚‹ ğ“…± ğ“‡³ğ“¤ rw nw prt m hrw; Arabic: ÙƒØªØ§Ø¨ Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙˆØªÙ‰â€ Kitab al-Mawtaa) is an ancient Egyptian funerary text generally written on papyrus and used from the beginning of the New Kingdom (around 1550 BCE) to around 50 BCE.[1] The original Egyptian name for the text, transliterated rw nw prt m hrw,[2] is translated as Book of Coming Forth by Day[3] or Book of Emerging Forth into the Light. "Book" is the closest term to describe the loose collection of texts[4] consisting of a number of magic spells intended to assist a dead person's journey through the Duat, or underworld, and into the afterlife and written by many priests over a period of about 1,000 years.
